bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, January 21, 1952

div1.p: Siler discusses the possibility of establishing a permanent exhibit of Walter Reed material, as well as the pros and cons of placing it at the Walter Reed Medical Center or the Army Medical Museum. Hench would be of great help in selecting material to be used in an exhibit. He hopes Hench's Cuba trip will result in the Cuban government furnishing funds for the preservation of Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, January 21, 1952
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
-----
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
January 21, 1952
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I wish first to apologize most humbly for my apparent neglect in
replying to your letters in the past month or so.

Doubtless you did receive the minutes of the annual meeting of the
Walter Reed Memorial Association Board of Managers and noted that there was
no important business transacted.

I would like to say, however, relative to the question of establishing
a permanent exhibit of Walter Reed material here in Washington that I have
talked this matter over with the Commanding Officer of Walter Reed Hospital
and with the Museum people here. They did have a small exhibit at the Mus-
eum during the period of the celebration of the hundredth anniversary of
Reed's birth. As you possibly know, the Armed Forces Institute of Pathol-
ogy is to be moved out to Walter Reed Medical Center. Funds already have
been provided for construction of a building but active construction is
being held up because of the shortage of materials. The question that we
should consider would be whether, in the event that a permanent exhibit is
prepared, it should be placed in the Institute of Pathology at Walter Reed
Medical Center or in the Army Medical Museum down on Constitution Avenue.
The present museum is of course very old and doubtless will be replaced at
some future time. It is probable that more people would see such an exhibit
if it were located here in the city rather than at Walter Reed.

I hope you will give this matter your consideration. There is no
hurry about deciding on the matter but it might be well to take some action
at the next annual meeting.

The second point, of course, is the question of collecting material for
such an exhibit. There is very little material available here but I have
no doubt that you can be of great help in selecting material to be used in
such an exhibit.

As I recall, it is your intention to visit Cuba in the near future. I
do hope so much that you will be able to make some headway in getting the
Cuban Government to furnish funds for the preservation of the building used
by Reed in his transmission experiments.

The Christmas holidays were ruined for the Siler family this year because
we both had virus pneumonia and are just now recovering from it.
With very best regards and all good wishes for the year ahead,
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. F. Siler
Col., MC, USA, Rtd. Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
